title: Colorful sine waves
description: Even though I have limited time to work on these, I've been trying to challenge myself to explore aspects of Scratch I haven't used before. Although I've known that you can use RGB colors in Scratch, I've never actually tried, and a long long time ago, I used to be really into geometry. So, this is a simple project, but it forced me to learn a little more about how to implement sine functions in Scratch, explore RGB color range, and also use the sensing color block! Looks simple, but I learned a lot. :)
instructions: Press the green flag to start, the stop button to clear, and move the sliders around to experiment with RGB colors.

title: Xylophone Music
description: I *really* wanted to make a Pac Man style game for today's challenge. After working on it for too long, getting super frustrated, and making dinner, I came back with a totally different idea. I wanted to see if I could do a xylophone game where the music was controlled by colors, as opposed to each xylophone key being a separate sprite. I'll keep working on my Pac Man project and share it another day :)
instructions:
Click the mallet to play music. Press "h" to add harmony to your song!

Press space to put the mallet(s) away.

title: Color Reader! (Getting Unstuck, Day 9)
description: When I first started the project, it was a bit of a disaster. I was using the original, full-color Starry Night and it was wayyyy too many colors to try to detect. I was feeling a bit demoralized and thought about abandoning the project entirely. And then I thought, "If I can't make the code easier (detecting these millions and millions of colors), could I make something _else_ easier?" And that's when I had the insight to make the image "easier" by reducing the number of unique colors in the image. (I found Van Gogh's Starry Night on Google's Art and Culture, took a screen capture of it, then reduced the number of colors in Photoshop.) Of course, it doesn't look as beautiful or as vivid as the original—but I think you can still tell that it's Starry Night. I'm excited about this prototype. :)
instructions:
My friend Dock is color blind. He occasionally appears in my office and asks what colors he's wearing (and if they make sense together). For today's Getting Unstuck challenge of color sensing, I was wondering how he experiences art.

Press the green flag, then move your mouse over the stage.

title: Drops
description:
This project was created for Day 9 of Getting Unstuck. Today's goal was to create a project that makes use of color sensing blocks. I wanted to create the feeling of objects falling alternately through air and fluid. Of course, there had to be some accompanying sound. 

If I were going to spend more time on this project, I would explore different instrument samples and more interesting chord progressions.

Vibraphone samples courtesy of University of Iowa Electronic Music Studios (http://theremin.music.uiowa.edu/index.html)
instructions: Press the green flag and enjoy!

title: Helicopter Doodler
description:
This project is inspired by a recent read -- 'The Boy Who Would be a Helicopter: The Uses of Storytelling in the Classroom' by Vivian Paley  

Doodle a scene from a story you've been dreaming, a frustration you've been feeling, something inspired by a project in a Getting Unstuck Studio -- whatever you'd like! 

Then, clear it away! 
(or take a screen shot and share it with a friend!)


I'm excited to create a program for creating! I'd like to play around with the keys/inputs. Perhaps on-screen buttons to press would be simpler. I'm also torn about including an "erasing' function. Thoughts?
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, bring the helicopter to a color on top and click the mouse to pick it up! 

Press p when you're ready to doodle
Press SPACE if you'd like to pause
Go to bottom left to change the size and shade of pen
                           (there are so many color possibilities!)
Press c to clear the canvas

title: Unstuck Day 9: Touching Color
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #9-using the touching color block- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
This was fun as it came together! The part I got stuck on was the prize sprite wasn't changing to the right color costume each time. It turned out both the arrow sprite and the prize sprite were doing something in triggered by receiving the prize broadcast and since the prize sprite conditions depended on a variable set by the arrow I had to add a slight delay to the prize sprite so the variable would have time to be set by the arrow. I find a lot of times things don't happen as you expect because of timing in Scratch.
instructions:
What will Dee get? Spin the wheel to choose a gift for Dee!
Argh I'm finding sometimes it doesn't work but I have to go to jury duty...will try to fix later. Hmm added a longer delay in the prize, seems to be working consistently.
Added some sound and an intro.
Still can't figure out why it sometimes picks the color it has gone past...
Ohh! I stupidly put the color detection in the arrow instead of the little dot that is more precise.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 9!

My biggest take-away from this project was to have the sprite rotate but for the costume to not rotate visually. 

I found Scratch has three rotation styles:
-Full rotation (default)
-Left/Right
-No rotation (this is what I selected)

This was helpful to get keep the sprites from ending up upside down or sideways.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9
description:
I have been thinking about line following robots. Seemed like the perfect opportunity to try out very simple rules, eg move forwards; if touching red turn right; if touching blue turn left. Seems to work surprisingly well. I like the idea that Scratch could be used to prototype real world robot algorithms.

I started with Scratch Cat rather than a ball, but extremities would "catch" on the colours and lead to twirling and getting stuck.

I'd like to experiment further with different angles and number of steps. Maybe with a timer to see how fast the ball completes the track. This could be automated to determine the best parameters.

More complex tracks would be fun. And maybe a player controller car to race the computer controlled (AI?) ball.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 9

Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?).

Just run the project and the ball will use simple rules to travel around the uncoloured track.

Like @karenb I struck the problem of too much depth of colour, but I think I picked up enough of them to get the idea.

There's still so much to do to improve this. With more time I'd add the ability to change the instruments of each sprite, and a slider to change the number of beats played. The Speed slider really doesn't change things as much as I'd like.

title: Getting Unstuck day 9
description: I started with one sprite bouncing around the stage and changing costumes. I duplicated this sprite twice. I did not realize that the conditionals that change their colors would be "True" when the sprites are touching each other (duh). Then I decided to add random "music" to the touching. I discovered that the notes and the color change/movement had to be in different scripts or else the sprites stopped moving after each step while the note played. The scale is G major in case you were wondering. I need to tinker some more with the speed the sprites are moving to see if the "music" could be a little more pleasing to the ear.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 9 — Generative Art
description:
Reflection

I wanted to improve on my Day 7 project in which multiple cloned pens draw sine waves to the screen. Instead of using dumb agents (that's the technical term) I integrated the color touch block so that the pens can respond to their environment.

The idea is simple, randomly pick a place to start a pair of smart agents, randomly choose a direction for the first agent and a user-defined offset (controlled by the slider) for the second, and let them move until they detect black, at which point they stop.

Overall, it works pretty well. However, one issue is the color touching block looks specifically for black. Because of anti-aliasing drawn lines, some of the pixels are dark grey and don't register with the color sensing block. I could complain, but I think the generated compositions look better because of this glitchiness.
instructions: Move the slider and watch as the art emerges.

title: Unstuck 09 Sensing colour
description: I always wanted to learn how to create a PacMan game, and a simple maze navigation seemed like a good start. Super happy with what I learned on this challenge. Next time I'd like to learn how to turn the maze walls into a sprite, and also how to have the ghost creatures auto traveling around.
instructions: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game.

title: Day 9 - Pre Symphony
description:
Sounds like symphony warming up. There must exist some algorithm to make it sound less discordant but my scope... Would also be fun to make the color light up when it is strikes but then each color would need to be a sprite. Additionally, there seems to be a timing factor in that the sprite has to sense the color at a certain pace for it to register. In any event, again, had a blast doing it and the sidetrack investigations were as compelling as the challenge. This is great! Though time is a factor, I definitely plan to stick it out.

Day 9 - Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game.
instructions: Click Flag

title: Music Bending Machine
description:
I've had to recreate this in Scratch 1.4 in order for my PicoBoard to work - but I know some people have success using later editions of Scratch, including web based Scratch, with Pico.   When Pico is connected, I like to replace the slider with a pressure sensor.

Problems I'm stuck on: I can't actually bend a note until the beat is complete, and then I can change the note before it repeats. I've settled on a beat of .15.  Does anyone know how to play a sustained note but bend the note while it is being played using a slider?
instructions:
Use with both MakeyMakey and a PicoBoard. Connect 5 spoons to Makey Makey's four arrows plus space bar. The program should allow one to bend notes using the sliding potentiometer. A note will be true if the potentiometer is set at 50.

Currently this is configured to play without the slider, and you can use your keyboard arrows and space bar. (There's a duplicate sprite that has the Pico blocks removed). Be sure to hit the green flag first.

The suggested starting sequence is up arrow, right arrow, left arrow, down arrow, space bar.

title: Day 9 Getting Unstuck Color Interactions
description:
My idea was to make an homage to Josef Albers and allow the user to change the colors noting that different colors would make the sizes of the boxes appear different but it's not working. :(

Everything appears to be on different layers so the shapes are going in front or behind each other so the sensing blocks are not working. You can see I got frustrated and tried a broadcast solution. I wanted to get unstuck myself before sharing.. but....
instructions:
drag the black ball around to change the colors but it's not working :(

I'm stuck!
I'm stuck about why the shapes are not on the same layer and thus unable to affect each other.
AND
I'm stuck about why I am unable to make a square without a border or with a transparent border.

Thinking about using touching color I thought of a drawing game. I structured a few things unlike how I usually would because I don't use the touching color much but it was fun experience.

Pretty fun making a single mouse press design and then hitting z to watch it go away on its own

The undo block works pretty well too. I was going to make it without screen refresh but I enjoy watching it backtrack over the last mouse down moves.

In game.

(I have to add the pen size, so this undo is assuming that the pen sized isn't changed prior to pressing z. )

title: Bouncing Watermelon -- Unstuck Challenge 9
description: Though this isn't a very elaborate project, it was good practice in seeing how to make sprites respond to elements on the page.  If I were going to work on this more, I'd want to add more interactivity with the user.  My original idea was to have a "Plinko" style game in which dropping the watermelon produced random results.  I decided that project would take too much time at this point, so I scaled down my original plan just to test out the features.  Perhaps with more time, I'll be able to return to my original idea.
instructions: Drag the watermelon anywhere on the page and watch what happens.

title: Day 9
description:
music - Edvard Grieg's Morning Mood from Peer Gynt via www.yourclassical.org

I really struggled with this and never got it to do what I wanted. The second I read the challenge I knew I wanted to make a chameleon. I can't draw well enough for that, so switched to a butterfly.
I fought with the color changing for almost an hour and a half! I WANT to be able to create a variable that senses color and then changes the sprite to match that color. I could not figure out how to do that. I tried to create a block that would recognize color, but no. I then fell back on "if touching color x" "set color to x". Looking up all the color values. That doesn't work - FYI - I still don't really know why.
I then simplified my background to only 4 (sorry about how lurid) colors and learned that the value you set in color is altered by the color at which your sprite starts! When it was white, the color change was so infinitesimal I couldn't really see it! Okay, turned it to a nice vibrant purple and then one color at a time experimented with numbers until they shifted to a reasonable approximation of the desired color.
Thanks to MrQuentin for bearing with the increasingly unhinged ranting that accompanied today's project and figuring out that part about the original color of the sprite affecting the color changes! 
I wonder if the previous iterations would work now that the sprite is purple, but will have to test that later.
instructions: Click the green flag!

title: Mouse Maze
description: I have also taught the basics of the ball interaction with the maze background to second grade students. They have created additional background mazes, but all their mazes start in the same x and y position. I removed the list of x and y coords to move the ball to different starting points for them.
instructions:
This game is designed for Kindergarten students to practice controlling the mouse. Click the green flag to begin, grab the purple circle with the mouse, and move it to the yellow finish line to get to the next maze. If you touch the red, you go back to start.

For the Getting Unstuck challenge, I have started adding additional obstacles and challenges to some of the mazes. Maze two has a narrow passageway, maze three has a disappearing/reappearing path, and maze six has a red wall sliding back and forth across the path. Any other ideas for obstacles? Please let me know.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 9
description: The hardest part of this project was choosing the sprites.  Realistic flowers made id difficult to use the "touching color" because of the shaded portions.  It was easier to use clipart with solid colors. The timing for the introduction was also tricky so that the reader can get through the introduction before the game begins.  I could have used broadcast events to time it easier, but choose wait blocks instead.

title: Infection v2
description: I chose to revist my project from the randomness day, which already used `touching color`. Adding both a third state (immune) and a "healing" zone increased the complexity of tracking states slightly and also forced me to think more critically about when I should be "infecting" - previously infected dots were trying to infect each other which caused unecessary slowdowns. I'm also playing around with the graphic effects a bit, which I've never toyed with much.

title: Unstuck Day 9

title: Donut Collector Take 2 - GettingUnstuck#9
description:
GettingUnstuck#9 - "Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?)"

This is a bit of a cheat as it is a copy of yesterday's mini game with "if touching sprite" replaced with "if touching color". 

I tried a different idea with a character moving and saying something when standing in a blue "puddle" or brown "mud". But I hit issue with "touching color" being true over and over and over and I couldn't think of a good way to move the sprite away from the colour fully.  I successfully got the sprite to bounce back the latest movement if it had just touched the colour. But then I realised that if I turned the sprite and more than a tiny part of it's body was in the colour then it got stuck!

Hopefully other people's project will give me hints to get around this.
instructions: Move the cat using the arrow keys. Collect all 10 donuts to complete the game.

title: GU_Day9_sidetracked
description: I was curious about the relationship between complementary colors. After reading an article, I learned they are opposite each other on the color wheel. I started playing with the idea of find complementary colors in clothes. This was fun to make. However, it does not follow the intent of Day 9. After I share this, it's back to work!
instructions: Click on the green flag, then choose what color blouse you would like. The project will choose a complementary colored skirt to wear with it.

The dog animation took me more time than expected to figure out, specifically, how to go back and forth how I envisioned. The Scratch Ed blog had some great user created examples which really helped.

(This is meant to be combined with a Makey Makey and custom controller.)

description:

If an atom cannot make a bond and continues to turn endlessly, you can press the SPACE Key to make it move towards other atoms.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9

title: Challenge20 - Platformer
description:
Disclaimer: this is an engine for a touching color game. I only have 2 levels drawn as examples. Wanted to create something extra using touching color and this came to mind. (Have to add x collision, whenI get back I will)

Had a few minutes and had always wanted to create a game where the user gets to play it how they want. I didn't have time for the whole game so I thought I'd create an engine with all condtions ready to go.

Red resets, yellow next level, too low on stage resets
instructions:
Redoing this from a few projects ago. Thought I'd see it through, add a few levels and few extra effects. Will add more levels when I have time. 

Draw bridges, platforms, whatever to get Scratch to the yellow. 

Arrow Keys left/right/up

You get 50 line points to draw platforms to get your cat to yellow

Space resets the level
Z to undo your last line

title: Magic colour ball
description: The main idea came from an interesting game developer studio called BinaryZoo. They made one of the best Asteroids clones ever, Echoes, which I tried to remake in Scratch (check my project Asteroidx) but the inspiration for this mini-game is Mono. In Mono you have to shoot at coloured blobs that leave a trail after they explode. The trail influences other blobs hovering upon them, like speeding up, making them spin towards you or shooting.
instructions:
Our hero has a magic ball that is influenced by colours! Red makes it spin anticlockwise while blue turns it clockwise.

First you have to paint the background. Aim the brush with the mouse and click to leave a spot. 1 & 2 change from red to blue. After you made the course, press space and the Cat will throw the ball in front of it!

title: Getting Unstuck #9: touching color blocks in the Sensing category
description:
Scratch project was created as activity #9 of the "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

Day #9 Challenge: Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?). For example, you could have a sprite moving around on a colorful background, with the sprite behaving differently depending on which color it is touching, like in a maze game.

Reflection:  Yesterday's unfinished "use a variable to count" project didn't go anywhere and so today it became a "use the color sensing blocks". 

I wanted to change the perspective and have the background move with the arrow keys instead of the Sprite. like this project: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/106716589/

I used the Scratch wiki on color settings to help me get unstuck.

title: Unstuck Day 9 - Colorful Fish
description: The challenge was figuring out what move blocks worked best to insure the fish traveled through the 5 different colors. When I tried using the random block with the glide block, he didn't always change color. I'm assuming it's because the proper part of his body didn't touch the color.
instructions: Press the flag to see the little fish swim through the colorful ocean waters. He will change based on the colorful of the water. There's a little surprise when he bumps into a starfish.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9: Germ Free?
description:
I know it's too much :)  
I wanted to try to make a Pac-man style game that modelled the immune system.  LOL.  
When part of a loop is moved and there is too many code, instructions got mixed up. (Next time, I will make numbered copies of draft versions.)
I do like the paths I created for sprites to follow. Put "guide" sprites along white path and told sprites to move from one to another, then hid them. Used "random" to vary routes. They worked nicely until I moved parts of the code.  
Wanted "Smiling Sprites" to turn to a frown when touching "Grumpy Spites".  Wanted "Grumpy Sprites" to change colour when they touched the "Grinning Blue Sprites".  Wanted to clone the moving sprites, but just had them create stamps along the path, which is somewhat entertaining. (Might have wanted too much.)
Technically, one or two "Grumpy Sprites" changed colour, so the objective of the challenge was reached (?)
Stay tuned for a simple project tomorrow :)
instructions:
Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category.
Watch sprites sort-of chase each other along the path. Press green flag to start.

I wanted to create something to use in the class, that was not a game type activity.
What started off as a simple naming of  the States and Territories then led me to adding additional information/images about the States and Territories.
Apologies to ACT which was too small to link - will have to work on this!
Can see this progressing to emblems, flags, etc.
I think I could have probably used different code to link the broadcasting without duplicating seven individual codes perhaps with a if then block.
Had to be careful when sprite is touching two colours again more time to be spent on recoding.

title: Synesthesia: Getting Unstuck Day 9 Touching Colour
description:
So, still not sure why I can't get my notes to synchronise. Even a single clone that plays a note sounds like 5 or 10 notes played not-quite-simultaneously.
Still not clear on how Scratch treats notes. Does the script stop while the note plays and then continue after or does the command to play the note go out and the script continue in parallel to the note playing?
>:-\
instructions: Press the Green Flag. There are two different patterns (that alternate each time you restart the project) of music to be played

title: Ceci c'est ne pas un projet
description:
Today I visited the SF Museum of Modern Art and completely felt in love with Magritte. So I decided to make something about it.

I've been spending more than 2 hours on a different project (inspired by the painting "Clear Ideas") but couldn't get anything good from it. I thought it was a great opportunity to check out again the "getting unstuck tip" on the website. 

I tried "Just Keep Going" for a while, but I was feeling more and more frustrated. I was inspired by the "Problem? Opportunity!" but still didn't know how to apply that to my super stuck situation.. Finally reading the "Try Something Different" gave me the courage and confidence to put all my previous work aside and start with a completely new project, and this time I tried to keep it as simple as I could.

I started with a simple painting of the sky, decided to add only one object, and focus on finding a way to use color sensing. I experienced the same problem of @karenb with the painting having many different colors. Then I realized that the different shades of gray of the clouds could become an opportunity to add a bit of randomness.. so the umbrella get stuck only when their handle touches a specific color.

Now it's 2:25am, and I'm exhausted, and joyful, and proud. 
This is not (just) a Scratch project!

Enjoy! :)
instructions: Click the green flag and be open to be surprised.

title: Unstuck Day 9 - Touch Color
description: I think there are a number of variations possible here, including letting the user navigate the car, and making the maze a little tighter. What would you do differently?
instructions:
Challenge:
Create a project that involves the touching color blocks in the Sensing category (i.e., touching color? and color is touching?).

So this is not really a game, just a way to test out the Touching Color blocks. Here is the goal: The car must reach the green square. It bounces off of black, but the black is occasionally modified by white squares that appear randomly throughout, thus allowing the car to temporarily go through the wall. The car is self-driving. The timer is there to see how long it takes to reach the goal, and after five minutes, the "journey" ends regardless. My lowest time is 27 seconds.

title: Unstuck Day 9 - Sensing Color
description: This started as an idea to get a bug to dance, but somehow turned into a game. I want to come back to it and clean it up sometime - I think it has the potential to be a fun little game.
instructions:
The object of the game is to get the bug to the orange from as far away as possible. Once activated the bug will move based on the color of the square it is above. You will have no control once it starts, so you must work backward from the orange and figure out where you can start from! Your score is the distance away from the orange when you start (if you successfully get to the orange!)

Click the Green Flag to create a random background. Move the bug to the square you want to start on (the little grey dot on the bug's back is the sensor) and click the bug to begin. Clicking Space will reset the bug to the center without changing the background.

title: Day 9 Getting Unstuck - paint bucket blueout
description:
This is incomplete, but it does use color detection per the Getting Unstuck challenge.

One difficulty I encountered was figuring out how to draw on a sprite with the pen. You can't do that, but you can use a stamp to get the image of a sprite on the backdrop then hide the sprite as suggested at https://scratch.mit.edu/discuss/topic/114508/?page=1#post-1008090.

I might be able to solve the bug by starting the drawing on the mid point of the area to be filled at the same y value where I clicked instead of starting at the click location. I ran out of time to pursue this since there are so many other challenges to try.  There is also another bug that shows up when trying to fill the start that's a little different.
instructions:
Click anywhere to fill all non-black areas of that object with blue. 
This runs painfully slow unless you use enable Turbo Mode (under the Edit menu) before running.

Bug: It does not fill above or below where you click if that area is narrower than where you clicked.

Can someone help me with this?
I want to be able to play a zoop sound when the ball is touched, but I can't get it to stop repeating the sound.  The answer is probably obvious.

I'm thinking that this might be simple project that I could use with my second graders.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 9
description: I started this as a basic maze and then I decided to add the inventory items to make it a little more challenging.  Since this was a color activity, they were just color circles otherwise, I would have tried to come up with a theme and used actual items that fit the story of why the main character has to make it through the maze.  If I had more time, I would add problems (math or word problems) when the ball touched each of the color circles.  You would have to get the answer correct to get the credit.  I enjoyed making this project.  Music
instructions: Click on the flag to begin.  Use the arrow keys to move the ball around the maze.  Don't touch the walls or you will have to go back to the beginning!  Make sure you gather all the items in your inventory before you get to the end of the maze.  Have fun!

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 9 Reflection:
This was my hardest challenge yet - I restarted this project a few times because I couldn't get it to work.  I think my problem was in choosing backgrounds from the library.  They have more color variation, so trying to make my sprite react to different colors didn't work properly.  This project is a lot simpler than I intended it to be (from a coding standpoint anyway!), but it's also the project I've learned the most from so far.
instructions: Click on play and use the arrow keys to help the mouse get to the cheesy puffs.  But don't touch the walls or you have to start over!

title: Unstuck Day 9 project

I was able to get this much to work and decided to leave it as is before I ran into more bugs. Good practice "getting unstuck" I guess! #unstuck #creativecomputing #sensing

title: Getting Unstuck Day 9 - Touching Colors
description: This was a cool activity. It reminds me of the dancing game back in the 90's. If I had time, I would like to the cat complete on task and then disappear and reappear in a new location. I would then click the sprite and then the new task would be performed. It would also be cool if I could have had the background have a watercolor effect. All I need is time... :)
instructions: Click on the green flag to start the program. Click on Scratch Cat to watch the performed task associated with the color of the grid.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 9 : My 2nd attempt!
description:
Okay, the journey to this project was two-fold.  I started by making a basic animation of the cat jumping on the beach background.  When he was touching the color of the sand he would jump and say that it was too hot, then return back to the sand and continue in a loop.  It was very basic, but it completed the challenge of the day.  I knew that I would have preferred to make my own background, like it was suggested in the email, but had never tried it before. 

Then I went to the library with my daughter and discovered the book, "Code Your Own Games" by Max Wainewright and one of the games was the 'Amazing Maze'.  So I had a lot of "help" with this one!  I would suggest drawing out your maze first.  I would also like to figure out how to make the cat bounce off the walls or edges if possible, or add an animation for completing the maze successfully.
instructions:
Click the green arrow to start the maze.

Use the arrow keys to guide Scratch the Cat through the maze.  If you touch any of the walls Scratch will turn around and move back.

Click the green arrow to start over.

instructions:

HINT: Examine the scripts for the ballerina. How do these work properly?
